body: +1 lgtm

Thanks everyone for reviewing this!

As @jzonthemtn commented, when I created this patch, I thought we could add the notice in the javadoc of TrainingParameters constructor so that users can know the existence of ModelUtil.createDefaultTrainingParameters(), but I noticed that the javadoc of ModelUtil.createDefaultTrainingParameters() says

> Note: Do not use this method, internal use only!

So I didn't touch them. :)

Can someone explain the background on this?

- Fix the checkstyle issue
- Commit message should be in imperative "No Jira - Add javadoc to normalizers"

otherwise +1
The test still fails. Please look at the JIRA ticket first: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/OPENNLP-1154

The previous PR has a bug. I fixed it and now all tests pass.

In this PR, I changed the XML config in postag to new format as well.

I haven't added any new tests for this, but I think I can add them in order to check the new format and back-compat support, but before implementing them, I'd like to know the feedback from committers. :)
+1 lgtm
+1 lgtm too
+1, lgtm

+1 lgtm, we should fix the commit message to include the issue number.

Let me just merge this.
Also ran full Eval test successfully to ensure rewritten test worked.

+1 lgtm

thanks everyone! I'll merge tomorrow after move the method to test package. thanks again!
Decided this should be fixed in the code generator instead of here.
Merged.
Since Java 6 you can use a wildcard in the classpath like this "lib/*". This should actually work as it is.
By looking at the jira issue I guess the issue is that the command was called from the wrong working director and then lib/* didn't create the correct classpath.
I'm going to close this until #303 is merged. I will then update and reopen this.

Eventually it would be nice to use the new feature generator format also for other components. The cache is only suitable as it is today for sequence generators (where the feature doesn't change based on the previous outcomes).

How would deal with this e.g. for langdetect? Disable it?

> How would deal with this e.g. for langdetect? Disable it?

For now, yes, just disable it.

- Could you please rebase this and solve the conflicts.
- And squash the commits.
Sorry the delays here!
@kottmann Done !

Perhaps you could add a description to the arguments of constructor BratNameSampleStream, since you are breaking constructor 1.8.4 compatibility. Its not cleat to me what I add in Set<String> nameTypes. All the nametypes I want to use? the ones to keep if overlapped?
I think you should add a Constructor that doesn't take "nameTypes".. Then I'll be happy, because then it doesn't break my code ;-)

There are more  usages of argmax in the OpenNLP source code.
I propose we create one common method and then try to only use that one.

We could move the ArrayMath to a more general package and place a common method there, or keep the existing one:
 https://github.com/apache/opennlp/blob/master/opennlp-tools/src/main/java/opennlp/tools/ml/maxent/quasinewton/ArrayMath.java#L90
any way to convert from alpha 3 to alpha 1?

I updated the patch along the following lines:

- rename maxIdx() to argmax() in the new ArrayMath class
- for the back-compat reason, add maxIdx() that calls the above mentioned argmax() to the previous ArrayMath class
- add more tests for argmax() which expects IllegalArgumentException
Would like to get an opinion on the softmax which is done in perceptron and maxent afterwards, can we unify that as well?
+1 lgtm

Thank you for the PR.

This needs to be squashed so that there is only one comment in the commit.  Also, Please create a JIRA ticket  (http://opennlp.apache.org > Development >  click on create a JIRA issue hyperlink).  Then change the name of the PR something a little for informative like "#XXX correct loop bounds" where XXX is the JIRA issue number.  Of course, you don't need to use exactly "correct loop bounds".
@danielruss  squashed the previous commits into one and also created a JIRA issue. Can you please verify.
@PrachiPrakash Thanks for the PR! Does this impact any existing unit tests?
@jzonthemtn  No, it doesn't impact any existing unit test
Commit message is not in the usual format, we can change it by using "Squash and merge".
Thanks for contributing this fix!
I'm guessing that with #322 merged this isn't needed now?
We should not merge this.
This is not the solution. Closing.

Sorry I think I now understand what happened: The `conll2003` specific part of the code actually only knows to take arguments `-lang eng` or  `-lang deu`, while the other parts of the code take `-lang en` as usual. Only the part of the documentation specific to conll2003 needs to be changed. I'll update my PR. 

Still not sure why a change was enacted CoNLL-2003 related part of the code after version 1.5.3 though. With 1.5.3 the argument was still `-lang en`.
Pushed the new change.
Withdraw this PR as this feature has been added to opennlp-addons.
A late +1 but built with Java 11
Any thoughts?

Guys, any thoughts?

If the testing is applicable, for the majority of languages the change in this PR has made the code slower. Should it be left like this?

Sorry for the late reply as I've been busy for my project.

Actually, when I merged this, I thought I doubted how this change improved the performance.

Let me withdraw this once as I don't have any particular reason to stick this change.
Thank you, Edd! I'm sorry for late reply. We've talked about this last week among committers. This is very nice contribution! I'll merge this soon.
cool ;-) LGTM

Thanks for sending us this PR.

Can you share details on how the code was generated? We might want to run the generator at some point in the future again and it would be nice to know how you did it.

Thanks, for the PR. I think we will not merge this change because the code is doing what the Javadoc is stating. This would then break it for all the users who expect it to work like described.

We would be happy to merge some other code to make using the dicationary easier, e.g. new method for iterations, etc.
Will we release the docker container as well?
Ok, thank you Kottmann =]

+1 and agree that some documentation would be helpful. Looking at our [Developer Documentation](https://opennlp.apache.org/docs/1.9.1/manual/opennlp.html) we don't have anything in there at all about stemming. We might should write that up as a separate task.
@kottmann No, intention was just to give a way to make an OpenNLP container locally. If there's a desire it's something we could look into.

Thanks for your review. All the documentation about generating the stemmers can be found on the [snowball website](http://snowballstem.org/runtime/use.html). 

The steps are:
- Download [Snowball](https://github.com/snowballstem/snowball)
- Build the Snowball compiler
- Call the Snowball compiler on the ```.sbl``` stemmer file of your choice among [those available](https://github.com/snowballstem/snowball/tree/master/algorithms). The ```-java``` option is used to generate Java code.

However, the stemmer files in this PR are slightly different from the output of the Snowball compiler. The ```methodname``` and ```methodobject``` arguments have been added to the ```Among``` objects instantiations, as you will find out that those are lacking from the Snowball compiler output.

@kottmann, We have worked on a demo site with a good support for multiple components (PFB demo video). Please let us know if you have any suggestions for improvements or would like to see more features. I have a git repo with the code base if you would like to consider hosting.

https://drive.google.com/open?id=1RE_WZ4tWyiWQ8Zunf5LmAgiAw7kps4mW

I'll squash the second commit on Monday.  Let me know what you think.
Correction...I'll probably make some further refinements on Monday and then squash.  No need to review now.
Updates made and squashed.  Let me know what you think.
Did you see a difference in detection performance with that change? Which languages would be affected?

I just confirmed that no current languages would be affected (not even those in the small set that I proposed adding on OPENNLP-1270) , and, frankly, the languages that are covered by codepoints beyond the bmp are rare (see e.g. [Supplementary Multilingual Plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_(Unicode)#Supplementary_Multilingual_Plane) and [Supplementary Ideographic Plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_(Unicode)#Supplementary_Ideographic_Plane).

However, I noticed zero difference in processing times for codepoints vs characters, and I feel that we should correctly handle lowercasing for languages that users might want to build their own models for.
When I make the updates in response to the discussion above, should I squash/force push or do you want to see the history from the initial PR?  Thank you, again!

I refactored the probing parts into LanguageDetectorME.  I removed the optimization that would allow for early stopping within a chunk for simplicity and to rely on the current {{ContextGenerator}} api.

I haven't squashed this because I do want to be able to revert if I misunderstood any of the above guidance.  I can squash before the final commit.

Let me know what you think.

We merge only one commit. So things would need to be squashed either by you or by GitHub when we merge. I personally prefer it when you could just send us one commit, but it doesn't matter much anyway because the GH button can do that for us.

> We merge only one commit.

Makes sense.  I'll squash when you're ok with the PR.

I propose to change the example for parsing. Reason: the current implementation of the parser fails to give a correct parse tree for the sentence "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog." It can be checked easily: the result doesn't have any verb! It should detect 'jumps' as a verb (VBZ) but instead it is tagged as a noun (NNS). Here is the current result from the docs page:

(TOP (NP (NP (DT The) (JJ quick) (JJ brown) (NN fox) (NNS jumps)) (PP (IN over) (NP (DT the)
    (JJ lazy) (NN dog))) (. .)))

It can be checked using other constituency parser such as stanford constitiency parser.

The suggested change allows using the MASC corpus in its current distribution in the stand-off annotation format. Supported annotations are:

- Sentences
- Tokens
- POS-tags
- Named entities

The module was tested against the whole MASC corpus, with adaptations made in order to handle errors in the corpus or compatibility issues between OpenNLP and MASC (e.g. named entity overlaps, sentence overlaps, zero-token sentences, etc.).

Because MASC is currently distributed according to CC-BY 3.0 (ASF Category B license), a set of fake files is included for testing purposes.
Build would fail on OracleJDK 8 installation. After switching to OpenJDK8, everything works.

Your build in Travis CI has the same issues as mine in[ OPENNLP-565:](https://github.com/apache/opennlp/pull/364#issuecomment-527124661) the installation of OracleJDK8 fails. You can fix that if you specify OpenJDK8 in the .travis.yml file.
@rdorado Thanks for the pull request! Did you make a JIRA ticket for this? Should there be two JIRA tickets -- one for changing the example and another to see if the parser can be improved?

@DomnulCiotlausi Thanks for the PR. I think there is another JIRA ticket for the JDK on Travis so it would be best to make that change under it instead of under your stemmer changes. Would you be able to revert your `.travis.yml` change?

Without this fix, pi (an index value of predLabels) would never be set to -1 which tells that a pmap (a Map object) does not contain a feature (a key). As a result, a NullPointerException is thrown because an int (a primitive) cannot be null. Therefore, the if-statement that follows (if (pi != -1)) can also never return false.
Is there a change in the `.travis.yml` file? If not, could it be removed from the pull request?
Thanks, I have removed `.tavis.yml` file from the pr.
@am6010 Awesome, thanks. How does this PR relate to #363?
Looks like we need to add `// CHECKSTYLE:OFF` as the first line to each of the generated stemmer files to satisfy checkstyle during the build.
Thanks for the contribution!

@jzonthemtn It is the same code with small changes in `SnowballStemmer` to get new instances for Indonesian and Catalan stemmers.  We were working in the same team with @DomnulCiotlausi but I couldn't commit to his brach directly so I raised a new pr.
Got it! Does that mean we should close the other PR in favor of this one?
@jzonthemtn  yes please.
Closing in favor of pull request #367.
@bagdemir It looks like the [Travis build](https://travis-ci.org/apache/opennlp) is back to successful. Is this change still needed?
This change breaks the build due to incompatibilities with some of the existing checkstyle rules. We can revisit this later if needed.

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.
If it is fixed, all good.

A change we need to make but I'm not sure how I feel about these automated pull requests. There's no JIRA to track the change and the commit doesn't reference the issue.
